results.title: Small island, big fight
results.creator_credit: Aven S Noah, Trevor Graham, Rosemary Hesp, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Junjidys Productions
results.brief_description: …Where I come from is Murray Island. We call it Mer. The home of the famous Mabo land rights case. We won that battle, but now we’ve got a new fight on our hands…this time with outside fishing fleets over who can profit from our waters. (Aven S. Noah) Situated on the eastern side of the Torres Strait between Papua New Guinea and Australia, Murray Island or Mer, is home to around 450 indigenous people with each family belonging to one of eight clans. Following the historic Mabo case which won recognition for traditional ownership of their land, the Mer people are now fighting for the same recognition of their sea - land and sea are all part of Aboriginal territory and have a historical cultural link to their spiritual beliefs and customs. Their sea is being invaded by commercial fishing fleets and local islanders are struggling to compete - already some have left the Island and three-quarters of the population are on welfare. What has not been resolved by the Mabo case must now be resolved by the Torres Strait Treaty which was designed to protect indigenous rights to fishing and environmental concerns. The documentary presents all sides to the argument including interviews with the commercial fishermen, Mer Island fishermen and community leaders, and legal representatives for the Mer people as well as archival footage of Eddie “Koiki” Mabo discussing sea rights in 1989. Narrated by Aven S. Noah.

results.title: Cry from the heart: the stolen generation
results.creator_credit: Jeni Kendell, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Gaia Films
results.brief_description: A confronting documentary which discusses the experiences of one Aboriginal family as a result of the Australian government’s policy in the first 70 years of the 20th Century of removing mixed Aboriginal children from their Aboriginal families and placing them in institutions or foster homes. The impact on thousands of Aboriginal families of being cut off from each other, their language and culture is evoked here in a very personal context. One family journey’s through the remembrance of the trauma of separation, confronting the consequences of it on their lives and the gradual process of being reunited and grieving for those family members they have lost. The progress of one family member is traced in detail from youth to time in jail to his release and his efforts to come to terms with his past and hopes for the future. Contains extensive interviews with family members, aboriginal support group leaders, and foster family members among others.

results.title: Gough Whitlam: in his own words [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Robert Francis, Interpares and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: This documentary opens with archival footage of Gough Whitlam’s 1972 election victory, campaigned under the now iconic slogan “It’s time”, which saw the end of a 23-year run in Australia of Liberal Federal government rule. In a contemporary conversation with John Faulkner, Whitlam discusses his history in politics during the 1950s, 60s and 70s - tumultuous times for Australia that saw immense social changes. Galvanised by the conservatism of the 1940s Whitlam joined the Labor Party, determined to deliver better community resources, such as hospitals and schools. Whitlam, an interesting and engaging speaker, with incredible powers of recall, discusses: conscription and Australian involvement in the Vietnam War; championing of equal pay for women; introduction of land rights for Aboriginals; liberalisation of immigration laws; Racial Discrimination Act; and founding the National Gallery of Canberra. Always a controversial figure, Whitlam was at times ridiculed and dogged by scandals and here he defends his role in Indonesia’s takeover of East Timor 1975. Covers in detail the double dissolution of 1974 and his dismissal by Governor General William Kerr. Whilst this documentary is thorough in its presentation of the issues and complexities of government, parliament and politics in Australia, interviewer John Faulkner seems at times sycophantic in his approach, compromising any impartiality.

results.title: Bridge over Myall Creek
results.creator_credit: Caitlin Shea, Margaret Parker, Wendy Page, John Millard, Helen Gasswill, Vanessa Gorman, Brigid Donovan, Samantha Butler and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Caroline Jones introduces this episode of “Australian story” which looks at personal reconciliation in action as demonstrated by the relationship between Sue Blacklock and Beulah Adams, descendants of victim and perpetrator in the 1838 Myall Creek massacre. Researching into her family history, Beulah Adams discovered her great uncle was one of the perpetrators in a massacre that saw 28 Aborigines killed. Beulah talks candidly about her reaction to the news, and her experience at meeting Sue Blacklock, descendant of one of the two survivors at a conference on reconciliation convened by Reverend John Brown. Another descendant of the perpetrators, Des Blake, talks about his experience at attending the memorial’s opening at Myall Creek in 2002, and how the experience has changed his life since then.

results.title: The Shame
results.creator_credit: Virginia Moncrieff and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program discusses domestic violence and sexual abuse in the Aboriginal communities in regional and outback Australia, where Aboriginal women are fifteen times more likely to be hospitalised and ten times more likely to die from domestic assaults than their white counterparts. There is also a frighteningly high rate of sexual abuse of young Aboriginal children and as Patrick Dodson (Chairman, Reconciliation Council 1991-97) quite poignantly remarks “At stake is the survival of Aboriginal people”. Rather than laying blame, reporter Liz Jackson attempts to find out why domestic abuse is so prevalent and what, if anything, is being done to improve conditions for the Aboriginal communities. Unemployment, alcohol abuse, boredom, low self-esteem, and cultural rituals contribute, it would appear, to the Aboriginal male aggression towards their family, and particularly their wives. Through interviews and personal stories, “The Shame” provides an insight into this most disturbing and tragic situation which exists among the indigenous people of Australia.

results.title: Fight for country
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description: All the Mirrar are together; we are united against any more uranium mining on Mirrar country…We have no choice - this is our land and our life, we can never leave, we must protect it. Yvonne Margarula, April 2002. Begins with a prologue (12 min.) entitled “An Unparalleled catastrophe” which briefly provides a background of the uranium mining industry, nuclear reactors, and the subsequent environmental disasters and health issues which have resulted world wide, including Chernobyl and its aftermath. The documentary then continues with “Fight for country” which tells the story of the Jabiluka Blockade - a campaign staged in 1998 by both indigenous and white Australians in protest against ERA’s (Energy Resources of Australia now Rio Tinto) recommendation to construct a second mine, Jabiluka, alongside of their Ranger Uranium Mine. Both the Ranger and Jabiluka leases are sited in the Kakadu National Park on Aboriginal sacred land. Over 5000 people from across Australia joined the Blockade and many thousands more participated in protests held throughout the major cities including Melbourne and Sydney. Support came from all walks of life, including Mandawuy Yunupingu of Yothu Yindi, Peter Garrett and Midnight Oil, Kev Carmody, Regurgitator, Coloured Stone, Gary Foley, Sen. Bob Brown, Bono (U2), Australian Conservation Foundation, Friends of the Earth, and most importantly from the Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation who provided the legal advice and direction for the Mirrar people in their fight for their rights. Also includes newsreel and archival footage, and backing by some great original music with strong political tones. For more historical background information about the Jabiluka Mine go to www.converge.org.nz/pma/cra0676.htm.

results.title: One night the moon [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Aanya Whitehead, Kevin Lucas, Paul Humfress, South Australian Film Corporation, OzOpera, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Film Commission and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Directed by Rachel Perkins (Radiance), “One night the moon” is the story of a young girl living on an outback station with her parents, who goes missing one evening after becoming enchanted by the moon. After assembling a crew of police and volunteers, the missing child’s racist father will not allow Albert, a gifted Aboriginal tracker, on his land. Albert (Kelton Pell) laments the fate of the helpless child, whose traces are eliminated by the searchers, ruining her chance of survival. Perkins distinguishes this drama by having the majority of the film sung by the principal characters, using minimal dialogue and exposition throughout the narrative. Paul Kelly, who co-wrote the score with Kev Carmody and Mairead Hannan, tackles the difficult character of a bigot, blinded by a prejudice that threatens the life of his daughter. The parents’ marriage cracks under the strains of their child’s fate as the father turns to alcohol for comfort. Filmed in the Flinders Ranges, the cinematography in the film is quite stunning, giving a tremendous sense of the boundless landscape and incredible beauty of the outback. Based on events that occurred in 1932.

Paul Kelly, who co-wrote the score with Kev Carmody and Mairead Hannan, tackles the difficult character of a bigot, blinded by a prejudice that threatens the life of his daughter. The parents’ marriage cracks under the strains of their child’s fate as the father turns to alcohol for comfort. Filmed in the Flinders Ranges, the cinematography in the film is quite stunning, giving a tremendous sense of the boundless landscape and incredible beauty of the outback. Based on events that occurred in 1932.

results.title: The Last Wave [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, James McElroy, Hal McElroy and Ayer Productions
results.brief_description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending Aborigines against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. Step by step a series of apparently random occurences assume a disturbing pattern. The city becomes a facade for a place of ancient ritual. Cast includes Richard Chamberlain and David Gulpilil and features photography by Russell Boyd. Features a digitally restored soundtrack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Weir, James McElroy, Hal McElroy and Ayer Productions

results.title: Road to the stamping ground
results.creator_credit: David Muir, RM Arts and Nederlandse Omroep Stichting
results.brief_description: A choreographical journey with Jiri Kylian of the Netherland’s Dance Theatre into the world of dance in Indigenous Australia. The documentary which opens the program follows Kylian’s visit to the Groot Eylandt tribal dance congregation in 1986 where his dance production Stamping Ground was first conceived. In Stamping Ground Kylian sought to underline the common qualities of ballet and Aboriginal tribal dance as well as fuse the two styles into a work that comments on the universal nature of human movement as a form of cultural and personal expression. Following interviews with the Dance company performers about the piece and footage of rehearsals demonstrating movements inspired by Kylian’s time at the Groot Eylandt congregation, the second half of the program is a presentation of the final performance of Stamping Ground by the Netherlands Dance Theatre Company.

results.title: Bangarra Dance Theatre: ochres
results.creator_credit: Stephen Burstow, ABC-TV (Australia) and Bangarra Dance Theatre
results.brief_description: Recorded during the 1996 Festival of Perth, this production is an exemplary work from the dancers and musicians of the Bangarra Dance Theatre Company, Australia, acclaimed for its fusion of contemporary dance and indigenous traditional styles as well as original musical scores. The performance is centred around the substance Ochres, a material with both physical and spiritual purposes in traditional and urban Aboriginal culture, and from which Stephen Page drew inspiration for his original creation of the choreography for the production in 1994. The dance performance is structured around the characteristics, qualities and variety of symbolic significances of the substance. Divided into 5 parts, it begins with the spirit of Ochres, ‘the light’, then the performance shifts to a study of Ochres’ four essential colours; yellow, black, red and white. The performance features Bangarra Dance Theatre Company artists Gary Lang, Marilyn Miller, Djakapurra Munyarryun, Russell Page, Albert David, Kathryn Dunn, Frances Rings and Gina Rings in a seamless video capture of a powerful dance work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Burstow, ABC-TV (Australia) and Bangarra Dance Theatre
